citation.article-title: Comamonadaceae, a new family encompassing the acidovorans rRNA complex, including Variovorax paradoxus gen. nov., comb. nov., for Alcaligenes paradoxus (Davis 1969).

p.s: Variovorax (Va.ri.o'vo.rax. L. adj. varius, various; L. adj. vorax, voracious; M.L. masc. n. Variovorax, [bacteria] devouring a variety [of substrates])
Cells are straight to slightly curved rods that are 0.5 to 0.6 by 1.2 to 3.0 μm and occur singly or in pairs.
Motile by means of degenerate peritrichous flagella.
Colonies are yellow because of the presence of carotenoid pigments.
Some strains are capable of lithoautotrophic growth in which hydrogen is used as an energy source; these strains have been described as biotype I.
The strains that are unable to use hydrogen have been described as biotype II (6).
Oxidative carbohydrate metabolism with oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.
Good growth is obtained on media containing carbohydrates, organic acids (including amino acids), or peptone.
The mean G+C contents of the DNAs range from 66.8 to 69.4 mol%.
In DNA-rRNA hybridizations, Variovorax strains have Tm(e) values of 79.0 to 81.O°C versus rRNA from Variovorax paradoxus ATCC 17713t1T.
The genus Variovorax belongs to the Comamonadaceae and is equidistantly related to the other taxa in this family (e.g., the genera Acidovorax, Comamonas, Hydrogenophaga, and Xylophilus).
The only species is Variovorax paradoxus (Davis 1969) comb. nov.
